conclusion: The v-t graph provides information about the velocity of the particle as a function of time.
The slope of the graph at any point represents the acceleration of the particle.
At t = 1 s, the velocity is v = 20 m/s.
At t = 2 s, the velocity decreases to v = 10 m/s.
The curve between t = 1 s and t = 2 s is not a straight line; it is curved downward.
The acceleration is not constant during the interval between 1 and 2 seconds.
The red tangent lines show the slope of the graph at different points between t = 1 s and t = 2 s.
At t = 1 s, the slope is steep (large negative acceleration).
As t progresses toward t = 2 s, the slope becomes less steep (smaller negative acceleration).
The magnitude of the acceleration is decreasing over time, indicating gradually decreasing acceleration.
The particle is moving in a straight line (linear motion) as implied by the v-t graph.
The velocity decreases from 20 m/s to 10 m/s, and the acceleration decreases in magnitude during this interval.
Yes, it is correct to say that the particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds.
